Award.AwardTitle: Enhancing Education and Awareness of Shannon Theory

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Consistent with the National Science Foundation's goal "to initiate and support ... programs to strengthen scientific and engineering research potential [and] science and engineering education programs at all levels", this project develops materials that will support education and broad awareness of the importance of key engineering advances . In particular, it will support creation of educational films and corresponding lesson materials for K-12 mathematics and science teachers that will allow students to be exposed not just to the advances in information theory, but also to how an ordinary person played a pivotal role in fostering them. By adapting material previously restricted to graduate-level courses and technical conferences to a larger audience, a broader dissemination of information theory should profitably inform teachers and researchers in other fields, thereby fueling the nation's STEM workforce and improving commercial technology.

This project focuses on the efforts and advances of Claude Shannon, who established the field of information theory by stating some of its most fundamental problems and solving them. The technologies that his work made possible form a major driving force of our economy. His information theory concepts provide the foundation for nearly every aspect of modern information technology and have been applied to many fields, including communication, language, genetics, computing, cryptography, psychology, perception, memory, artificial intelligence, quantum physics, and others.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Claude Elwood Shannon, 1916-2001, was an American Mathematician and Engineer, widely credited with revolutionizing modern communication theory and founding the field of information theory. Some even consider him to be the father of the information age. 


To commemorate Shannon's birthday centennial, the information theory society commissioned a documentary, named "The Bit Player", about Shannon's life and work and the creation and impact of information theory. The documentary was written, directed, and produced by Mark Levinson, a physicist by training, who had previously produced a successful documentary, Particle Fever, about the discovery of the Higgs boson. 


The documentary is framed around a dramatization of an extensive set of interviews that Shannon gave in the 1980's. The recreated interview is conducted by a "graduate student", played by Kaliswa Brewster, with John Hutton and Judith Ivey, playing Claude Shannon and his wife Betty. All three are established stage actors. The interview takes place at the "toy room" in Shannon's longtime Winchester, MA, house, where many of the gadgets Shannon created were reassembled and are used as props and conversation and illustration pieces. 


The interview is interleaved with flashbacks to many aspects of Shannon's life, including his childhood, adolescence, college days, relationships, family, of course professional life and technical career, and all the way to the onset of cognitive decline. Many people who played important roles in Shannon's life appear, including his girlfriend Maria Moulton-Barrett, first wife Norma Barzman, his son Andrew, and daughter Peggy.


Consistent with the film's educational mission, it pays special attention to Shannon's many technical contributions. These are explained in part by his students Danny Hillis, and Leonard Kleinrock (recipient of the National Medal of Science, UCLA) his colleague Robert Gallager (Professor emeritus, MIT), and several information theorists ranging from very senior, such as Alexander Vardy and Andrea Goldsmith (who narrates the film's technical aspects) to very junior, e.g., Yana Shkel, Victoria Kostina, and Marco Mondelli.


Extensive graphics and accompanying narration help illustrate and explain several concepts and techniques Shannon invented, such as the bit, entropy, and capacity. In particular the film follows the prolonged race to derive error-correcting codes that achieve Shannon's Limit, starting from Shannon showing their existence in 1948, to the discovery of their practical implementation by turbo codes in 1993. 


Important implications of Shannon's work to compression, communication, storage, and cryptography, are also explained. Authors Jimmy Soni and Rob Goodman wo co-wrote a recent biography about Shannon, A Mind at Play, provide a general context, while industrial captains and academic leaders portray applications to specific fields. Eric Schmidt (CEO of Google / Alphabet) describes implications to the information age, Henry Markram (founder of the human brain project, EPFL) illustrates information storage in the brain, and Nima Arkani-Hamed (Princeton) explains implications of information to physics and cosmology.  


The film informally premiered at the June 2018 Information Theory Symposium in Vail, Colorado, and was since shown at the 2018 Science Media Awards & Summit in the Hub (SMASH), where it was one of three finalists in the Technology and Innovation category. It was also chosen as "Best of Show" in Realscreen's 2019 MIPTV issue. The Information Theory Society contracted distribution company "Off the Fence" to distribute the film. The film's website and trailer can be seen at http://thebitplayer.com
